children.text: Standard: Performing

Students will:
  • sing, alone and with others, a varied repertoire of music; and
  • perform on instruments, alone and with others, a varied repertoire of music.
participate in singing a variety of songs.
sing loudly and softly.
sing high and low pitches.
echo a simple rhythmic pattern.
perform steady beat and melodic rhythm.
perform rhythms using quarter notes, quarter rests, beamed eighth notes, half notes and half rests.
communicate by moving expressively to music.
demonstrate slow and fast tempi through movement.
demonstrate high and low pitches through movement.
demonstrate strong and weak beats through movement.
demonstrate AB form through movement.
perform an accompaniment to a song, i.e., rhythm instruments, melodic instruments, or body percussion.

Students will:
  • sing, alone and with others, a varied repertoire of music; and
  • perform on instruments, alone and with others, a varied repertoire of music.
expand singing songs in major and minor keys.
sing or perform an ostinato.
sing two part round and partner songs.
perform syncopated patterns.
perform rhythmic patterns from notation.
play melodic patterns from notation.
play chords to harmonize melody
accompany singing on a variety of classroom instruments.
perform rhythmic and melodic patterns to add special effects to songs.
demonstrate presto, moderato, andante, and largo through movement.
demonstrate ritardando and accelerando and a tempo through movement.
perform music containing crescendo and diminuendo.
communicate ABA form through movement.
communicate rondo form through movement.
sing or play instruments, following the cues of a conductor.

Students will:
  • sing, alone and with others, a varied repertoire of music; and
  • perform on instruments, alone and with others, a varied repertoire of music.
sing songs and/or play instruments in unison and two-part harmony.
sing and play major/minor melodies.
play major/minor chords.
perform music in a variety of global styles (e.g. classical, folk, jazz, etc.)
perform compositions and/or accompaniments on instruments.
Standard: Exploring

Students will:
  • read and notate music;
  • listen to, analyze, and describe music; and
  • evaluate music and music performances
identify and distinguish uses of the voice, i.e., whisper, shout, speak and sing.
identify and manipulate/notate high and low pitches on a music staff.
identify steps, skips, and leaps in staff notation.
distinguish between steady beat and rhythmic patterns.
read notation for quarter notes, quarter rests, beamed eighth notes, half notes and half rests.
read rhythmic notation in 2/4 and 4/4 meter.
distinguish between same and different musical phrases.
identify introduction and coda.
identify same and different sections of music, e.g., AB form, verse/refrain staff.
identify and demonstrate proper use of repeat signs.
define piano (p) and forte (f).
define Allegro and Adagio.
evaluate their own musical performance, e.g., pitch, dynamics, tempo.
identify musical instruments, e.g., classroom, symphonic, folk, global, etc.

Students will:
  • read and notate music;
  • listen to, analyze, and describe music; and
  • evaluate music and music performances
identify aurally and visually orchestra, band and folk instruments.
distinguish between an orchestra and a band.
expand previously learned notation to include single eighth notes and rests and beamed sixteenth notes.
expand previously learned notation to include whole notes and rests and dotted half notes.
read notation for songs.
read rhythmic notation in 3/4 meter.
identify a treble clef.
identify bass clef.
identify notes on the treble clef staff by letter name.
identify use of sharps and flats.
manipulate/notate notes for the major scale.
identify pp, p, mp, mf, f, ff dynamics.
recognize the symbols for crescendo and diminuendo.
identify the four vocal parts: soprano, alto, tenor, bass.
identify and demonstrate staccato and legato.
identify and demonstrate fermata.
identify ritardando, accelerando and a tempo.
identify and demonstrate first and second endings.
identify and demonstrate D.C. al Fine and D.S.
identify ABA form.
evaluate their own musical performances.

Students will:
  • read and notate music;
  • listen to, analyze, and describe music; and
  • evaluate music and music performances
aurally identify soprano, alto, tenor, and bass voices.
visually and aurally identify musical instruments (e.g. traditional, folk, electronic, global, etc.).
aurally distinguish between major and minor tonalities.
review and refine all previous learned notation and musical forms.
read rhythmic patterns from 2/4, 3/4, 4/4, and 6/8 meters.
identify in 6/8 meter.
identify and notate dotted quarter notes.
expand previous notation to include dotted rhythms.
explore grand staff notation.
read notation for the bass clef and treble clef.
follow a musical score.
identify modulation.
interpret tempo markings and dynamics.
interpret D.C., D.S., first and second endings.
evaluate vocal and instrumental performances.
Standard: Creating

Students will:
  • improvise melodies, variations, and accompaniments; and
  • compose and arrange music within specified guidelines
improvise a melodic or rhythmic phrase.
create appropriate sounds to accompany stories or poems.
compose a rhythmic or melodic pattern to represent a character in a story.
improvise on a melodic instrument within specified guidelines.
improvise a rhythmic accompaniment for a song.
compose an original composition.
compose a piece of music in AB form.

Students will:
  • improvise melodies, variations, and accompaniments; and
  • compose and arrange music within specified guidelines
improvise music questions and answers.
compose a piece using different dynamic levels.
given a theme, create variations on that theme.
compose a song in ABA form.
compose a piece using rondo form.

Students will:
  • improvise melodies, variations, and accompaniments; and
  • compose and arrange music within specified guidelines
improvise on percussion instrument e.g. drum circle or percussion ensemble.
improvise on a melodic instrument e.g. ii V I; blues.
compose melodies using major/minor tonalities.
compose a piece in 2/4, 3/4, 4/4, 6/8 meter.
Standard: Relating

Students will:
  • understand relationships between music, the other arts, and disciplines outside the arts
  • understand music in relation to history and culture
relate music to other disciplines, e.g., children's literature, math, science, visual art, etc.
discuss social responsibility through appropriate audience behavior.
demonstrate civic literacy by singing and discussing American folk songs and songs with patriotic texts.
sing and discuss Appalachian, global, and holiday songs.
compare singing games from various global cultures.
discuss how music is used in daily life, e.g., television, radio, Internet, etc.
discuss the roles of musicians in society.
identify instruments unique to various global cultures.
discuss Italian origin of music terminology.

Students will:
  • understand relationships between music, the other arts, and disciplines outside the arts
  • understand music in relation to history and culture
collaborate with others in a musical play.
create a visual artwork for a piece of music or create music for visual art.
compare and contrast works of art and music that are based upon the same event, subject, or mood.
relate ABA forms in related arts.
sing and interpret foreign language songs from global cultures.
refine the use of Italian in music terminology.
develop civic literacy by singing West Virginia and patriotic songs.
sing spirituals, gospel songs, and work songs and recognize their roles in American history.
identify and discuss tone production for instruments and voices.
explore musical careers, e.g., conductor, composer, accompanist, etc.
explore 21st century life skills relevant to musical careers, e.g., leadership, ethics, accountability, etc.
discuss and demonstrate social responsibility through appropriate audience behavior.

Students will:
  • understand relationships between music, the other arts, and disciplines outside the arts
  • understand music in relation to history and culture
develop civic literacy by singing and relating West Virginia songs to West Virginia history and geography.
explore and characterize music from various global cultures.
examine the science of acoustics.
use information and communication technology to examine the financial, economic, business and entrepreneurial aspects of musical careers.
discuss the evolution of musical styles, including their relationship to historical events.
discuss and demonstrate social responsibility through appropriate audience behavior in a given setting.
Standard: 1 Performing

Students will
  • perform on instruments, alone and with others, a varied repertoire of music.
match pitches.
keep a steady beat and perform given rhythms.
play pizzicato and arco with resonant tone quality.
demonstrate correct posture, playing position, and bow control.
echo patterns played by the teacher.
play a simple, familiar melody by ear.
play global folk tunes and rounds in the keys of D and G major.
play from memory the major scales of D and G.
play a piece utilizing piano and forte.
play intervals formed with one fingered and one open string. (Omit double bass.)
play octaves and identify octaves played in tune.
use detaché bowing to play legato melodies.
play legato melodies marked with two-note slurs.
play staccato passages.
interpret accents.
develops personal productivity through practice habits.
Standard: 2 Exploring

Students will:
  • read and notate music
  • listen to, analyze, and describe music
  • evaluate music and music performances
read notated music containing whole, half, quarter, eighth, and dotted quarter notes and rests in meters of 2, 3, and 4.
identify incorrectly played rhythms.
notate quarter notes and rests.
add bar lines to an example containing none.
respond verbally, using correct names of notes, the staff, rhythms, clefs, and meter signatures when questioned about a line of music.
identify AB and ABA form.
listen to exemplary models of instrumental performances.
distinguish between appropriate and inappropriate tone quality.
classify a piece as played in tune or out of tune after listening to a performance.
differentiate between octaves, unisons, and fifths presented aurally.
interpret the following: repeat sign, D.C. al Fine, D.S. al Fine, multiple endings.
play a melody in temp andante, allegro and in tempo moderato.
evaluate their own performances.
Standard: 3 Creating

Students will:
  • improvise melodies, variations and accompaniments.
  • compose and arrange music within specified guidelines.
create a response to a rhythmic pattern performed by the teacher.
create a response to a melodic pattern performed by the teacher.
Standard: 4 Reading

Students will:
  • understand relationships between music, the other arts, and disciplines outside the arts
  • understand music in relation to history and culture
relate note values to fractions in math.
discuss the principles of sound and pitch production on string instruments.
perform folk tunes from various global cultures.
listen to a performance of a folk tune and discuss its cultural background.
compile a list of how music is used, e.g., commercials, movie/TV themes, church music, and answer questions as to why music is used in everyday life.
discuss social responsibility through appropriate audience behavior.
Standard: 1 Performing

Students will:
  • perform on instruments, alone and with others, a varied repertoire of music.
play melodies and major and minor scales in keys up to 3 sharps and 1 flat.
play music containing dotted rhythms, eighth-note triplets, sixteenth notes and rests in meters of 2, 3, 4, 6 and alla breve.
demonstrate characteristics of good ensemble playing.
play melodies marked with 3-note slurs.
play slurred melodies incorporating string crossings.
play with slurred staccato bow strokes.
play non-legato melodies.
perform using martelè and lourè bow strokes.
play syncopated rhythms.
participate in the performance of a Baroque piece.
play with extended finger positions in the first position.
perform melodies using chromatic tones and play a chromatic scale.
play sixths in firs position (omit double bass).
play unisons and octaves formed with 1 open string and one string fingered in 3rd position (‘cellos and basses in 4th position.)

play melodies which, because of extended range or convenience of finger patterns, require the use of positions other than first. These positions are different for the various stringed instruments. Thus, they are specified as follows: violin and viola – 3rd position; cello – half, 2nd, 3rd, and 4th positions and extensions; bass – half, 2nd, and 4th positions and extensions.
develop accountability and personal productivity through practice habits.
Standard: 2 Exploring

Students will:
  • read and notate music
  • listen to, analyze, and describe music
  • evaluate music and music performances
sightread pieces in major and minor containing various bowing and articulations.
interpret music using contrasting dynamics including pp, p, mp, mf, f and ff.
identify the following in a given piece of music: slur and staccato marking; key signature; sixteenth notes, dotted notes, and eighth note triplets.
identify and define crescendo, diminuendo, ritardando, sforzando, a tempo and femata.
interpret the tempos allegretto and adagio.
identify the following: introduction, coda tonal center.
identify like and unlike phrases and sections
identify minor melodies presented aurally.
tune his/her instrument.
write major scales and specified intervals above a given note.
list characteristics of good solo playing and good ensemble playing, e.g., type of tone quality, intonation, rhythmic precision.
distinguish between good and poor intonation, correct and incorrect rhythms, good and poor tone quality in their own performance.
critique a performance.
Standard: 3 Creating

Students will:
  • improvise melodies, variations, and accompaniments
  • compose and arrange music within specified guidelines
improvise a rhythmic variation on a melody.
improvise a response to a simple melody played by the teacher.
improvise a musical phrase according to parameters provided by the teacher.
create and notate a musical example in a given meter and key, using correct pitch and rhythmic notation, clef, and key signatures.
Standard: 4 Relating

Students will:
  • understand relationship between music, the other arts, and disciplines outside the arts
  • understand music in relation to history and culture.
discuss the difference between fiddle and violin music.
demonstrate simple fiddle techniques.
trace the global origins of Appalachian fiddle music.
discuss the art, music, and dance of the Baroque period.
compare phrases to sentences in language arts (antecedent and consequent phrases).
discuss the characteristics of music genres and styles studied.
discuss and demonstrate social responsibility through appropriate audience behavior.
Standard: 1 Performing

Students will:
  • perform on instruments, alone and with others, a varied repertoire of music
perform ensemble music (e.g., string orchestra works, full orchestra works, chamber music) from various time periods.
refine characteristics of good ensemble playing.
play melodies and scales in major and minor keys up to 5 sharps and 4 flats.

play melodies which, because of extended range or convenience of finger patterns, require the use of the higher positions. These include (but are not limited to) the following: violin and viola – 2nd through 5th positions; cello and bass – half through 6th positions and extensions. (Include thumb position for cello and extreme upper positions of bass.)
review and refine bowings, expanding to include spiccato.
play pieces containing irregular and/or changing meters.
play double stops, arpeggiated chords, trills and grace notes.
play 3 and 4-note cords.
play a melody con sordino.
play using vibrato.
demonstrates accountability and personal productivity though practice habits.
Standard: 2 Exploring

Students will:
  • read and notate music
  • listen to, analyze, and describe music
  • evaluate music and music performances
sightread music containing the temp markings largo and accelerando, contrasting dynamics, subito p and subito f.
listen to compositions by different composers and describe the elements of music and expressive devices that make each unique.
interpret tempo, dynamic, and expressive terms and symbols used in a piece of music, e.g., andante, accelerando, sfz, col legno.
create a list of characteristics of exemplary playing including techniques and expression.
describe the compositional techniques used in a theme and variation.
interpret the symbol for a turn (~).
identify counter melodies in recorded, played or written examples.
describe various orchestral forms (e.g., rondo, sonata, allegro, etc.)
play a piece that makes use of non-standard notation.
compare and contrast timbre, dynamics, and form in two orchestral pieces.
describe feelings evoked while listening to a musical work and list what elements of music contributed to those emotions.
compare and contrast student performances with those of professional groups.
Standard: 3 Creating

Students will:
  • improvise melodies, variations, and accompaniments
  • compose and arrange music within specified guidelines
create melodic variations on a given melody.
add trills and grace notes to a major or minor melody,
create a melody in the style requested by the teacher.
perform an improvisation (e.g., jazz, blues, bluegrass, aleatoric).
Standard: 4 Relating

Students will:
  • understand relationships between music, the other arts, and disciplines outside the arts.
  • understand music in relation to history and culture
compare recordings of musical works from the Classical and Romantic periods; discussing similarities and differences.
describe ways in which music is related to a foreign language, mathematics, and science.
create a list various roles that musicians perform, cite representative individuals in each role and describe their activities and achievements.
compare the processes used in composing music and creating visual arts including the basic content of each art form, e.g., unity and variety, repetition and contrast.
discuss how music has reflected historical events and culture.
discuss the use of stringed instruments in American music genres, e.g., folk music, jazz, pop.
list the musical characteristics that contribute to a given musical work's placement in a time period.
discuss and demonstrate social responsibility through appropriate audience behavior in a given setting.
Standard: Performing

Students will:
  • perform on instruments, alone and with others, a varied repertoire of music.
show proper instrument assembly, maintenance, hygiene and cleaning.
display correct posture and instrumental playing techniques.
keep a steady beat.
echo rhythmic and melodic patterns.
match pitches with good intonation and tone quality.
perform beginning level music.
play an instrumental solo.
play music containing harmony.
play melodies containing slurs.
play a variety of beginning percussion instruments, e.g., snare drum, bass drum, and cymbals (percussion only).
develop personal productivity through practice habits.
Standard: Exploring

Students will:
  • read and notate music;
  • listen to, analyze, and describe music; and
  • evaluate music and music performances
identify by sound musical instruments used in beginning band.
differentiate between good and poor tone quality.
identify like and unlike musical phrases and/or sections.
read quarter, half, whole, and eighth notes and rests in meters of 2, 3, 4, and alla breve.
identify the clef and the names of the lines and spaces.
play notated melodies in concert Bb and Eb major.
play exercises that include single strokes, five-stroke rolls, nine-stroke rolls, long rolls, and flams (percussion only).
interpret the following: repeat sign, D.C. al Fine, D.S. al Coda, multiple endings.
discuss criteria for evaluating music performances.
sight-read a short melody.
play the B flat concert major scale.
interpret piano, mezzo-forte and forte with their symbols.
Standard: Creating

Students will:
  • improvise melodies, variations, and accompaniments; and
  • compose and arrange music within specified guidelines.
improvise using two to three pitches.
create a response to a rhythmic pattern performed by the teacher.
Standard: Relating

Students will:
  • understand relationships between music, the arts, and disciplines outside the arts; and
  • understand music in relation to history and culture.
describe the method of tone production for brass, woodwind, and percussion instruments as it relates to the principles of sound production.
explore and perform folk songs and global music as presented in the method book.
develop civic literacy through the study of patriotic selections.
discuss social responsibility through appropriate audience behavior.
Standard: Performing

Students will:
  • perform on instruments, alone and with others, a varied repertoire of music.
demonstrate characteristics of proper ensemble playing, e.g., balance, blend, intonation.
play music containing increased range and contrasting dynamic levels.
perform graded band music, using appropriate expression, articulation, posture and tone production.
play timpani and perform using two-hand technique on mallet percussion (percussion only).
play a chromatic scale and major scales up to three sharps and three flats.
play pieces in major and minor tonalities.
play a minor scale.
play a familiar melody by ear.
play syncopated rhythms.
develop accountability and personal productivity through practice habits.
Standard: Exploring

Students will:
  • read and notate music;
  • listen to, analyze, and describe music; and
  • evaluate music and music performances
identify and demonstrate conducting patterns in 2, 3 and 4.
review and refine previously learned rhythms.
identify sixteenth notes, eighth note triplets, and dotted rhythms.
play ruffs, ratamacues, five-stroke rolls, nine-stroke rolls, seventeen-stroke rolls, flam accents, flam taps, and single and double paradiddles (percussion only).
perform music in 6/8 time.
interpret allegro, moderato and andante.
interpret the markings for ritardando.
identify key changes.
interpret staccato, accents and fp.
interpret pp, p, mp, mf, f, ff, crescendo and diminuendo.
sight-read in a major key.
tune using an electronic tuner.
identify AB and ABA forms.
evaluate personal performances and performances by others.
Standard: Creating

Students will:
  • improvise melodies, variations, and accompaniments; and
  • compose and arrange music within specified guidelines.
create a response to a melodic pattern performed by the teacher.
improvise a musical phrase according to parameters provided by the teacher.
compose a simple melody.
Standard: Relating

Students will:
  • understand relationships between music, the arts, and disciplines outside the arts; and
  • understand music in relation to history and culture.
relate note subdivision to simple mathematics.
perform music from different global cultures and historical periods.
analyze the style and characteristics of musical genres, styles and cultures studied in band.
use information and communication technology to examine musical careers.
discuss and demonstrate social responsibility through appropriate audience behavior.
develop civic literacy through the performance of patriotic selections.
Standard: Performing

Students will:
  • perform on instruments, alone and with others, a varied repertoire of music.
perform in a large ensemble, e.g., concert band, wind ensemble, marching band.
refine characteristics of good ensemble playing.
perform graded music.
play triplets and swing eighth notes.
play melodies with changing meters.
play rubato passages.
play conducted tempo and dynamic changes.
play ornaments, e.g., grace notes, trills, and turns.
play staccato, marcato, and legato.
demonstrate different combinations of articulation.
demonstrate proper playing techniques on a variety of percussion instruments, e.g., drum set, accessories, world percussion (percussion only).
interpret an instrumental solo passage with proper style.
demonstrates accountability and personal productivity through practice habits.
Standard: Exploring

Students will:
  • read and notate music;
  • listen to, analyze, and describe music; and
  • evaluate music and music performances
play and notate scales up to four sharps and four flats.
play major and minor arpeggios.
play rudiments including, but not limited to, the 26 standard American drum rudiments (percussion only).
play and sight-read melodies in major and minor keys up to four sharps and four flats.
identify and interpret musical symbols, terms, dynamic changes and odd and/or mixed meters.
perform a piece using non-standard notation symbols.
explain how tempo terms relate to metronome markings.
identify counter melodies.
describe how the elements of music are used in a given work to make it unique, interesting and expressive.
discuss how the elements in a given musical work elicit an emotional response.
develop a list of criteria to be used in the evaluation of musical performances.
compare student performances with those of professional groups.
compare and contrast different musical selections analyzing the form, style, musical era, etc.
Standard: Creating

Students will:
  • improvise melodies, variations, and accompaniments; and
  • compose and arrange music within specified guidelines.
create melodic variations on a given melody.
perform an improvisation, e.g., jazz, blues, aleatoric.
improvise background "fills" (percussion).
compose, notate and perform a melody.
Standard: Relating

Students will:
  • understand relationships between music, the arts, and disciplines outside the arts; and
  • understand music in relation to history and culture.
explain the acoustical properties of particular instruments.
identify and compare musical characteristics of a variety of genres, styles, historical periods and cultures.
discuss how the elements of music compare with those of the other arts, e.g., balance, form, mood, etc.
analyze and explain how the elements of music can be used to evoke feelings or to describe places or events.
assess the importance of major American musicians.
analyze and explain the style and historical context of American musical selections performed in band.
discuss and demonstrate social responsibility through appropriate audience behavior in a given setting.
develop civic literacy through the performance of the National Anthem.
Standard: 1 Performing

Students will:
  • Sing, alone and with others, a varied repertoire of music.
sing unison and two-part music.
sing scales and vocal warm-ups within their vocal range.
sing rounds and partner songs.
sing music with various dynamic levels.
sing a variety of choral literature, e.g., regional, national, global.
sing using various singing styles, e.g., jazz, gospel, classical.
sing using correct attacks and releases.
sing with proper vocal technique, e.g., posture, breath support, pitch.
sing with metrical and textual accents.
echo rhythmic and melodic patterns.
sing using various articulations, e.g., legato and staccato.
match given pitches.
maintain a steady pulse while performing rhythms.
demonstrate proper ensemble singing characteristics, e.g., balance, blend, etc.
develops personal productivity through practice habits.
Standard: Exploring

Student will:
  • read and notate music
  • listen to and describe music
  • evaluate music and music performances
read and sing literature containing various rhythmic notations, e.g., whole, half, quarter, eighth, sixteenth, dotted notes and rests.
identify pitches on a staff.
sing music from a notated score.
sight sing melodies in appropriate clefs.
identify and notate various meters, dynamics, and tempo markings.
aurally identify major and minor tonalities.
identify musical phrases and various forms, e.g., AB or ABA .
identify voice classifications, e.g., Soprano, Alto, Tenor, Bass. .
identify breath marks and musical phrases.
identify syncopated rhythms.
listen to exemplary models of quality choral performances.
develop criteria for quality choral performances.
evaluate various types of choral literature.
identify intervals, e.g., steps, skips, leaps.
interpret musical symbols, e.g., bar lines, measures, ties, accidentals, fermata, repeat sign, D.C. al Fine, D.S. al Fine and multiple endings.
discuss the function of the accompaniment
Standard: Creating

Students will:
  • improvise melodies, variations, and accompaniments
  • compose and arrange music within specified guidelines
improvise a melodic or rhythmic response.
create new lyrics for a known melody.
collaborate to compose a vocal warm-up.
Standard: Relating

Students will:
  • understand relationships between music, the arts and disciplines outside the arts
  • understand music in relation to history and culture.
identify physical characteristics and anatomical characteristics of vocal tone production.
explain how the text affects choral interpretation.
describe the stylistic differences of selected global choral literature.
discuss the role of the conductor and accompanist
discuss concert etiquette as a performer and audience member.
relate note values to fractions in mathematics.
discuss social responsibility through appropriate audience behavior.
Standard: Performing

Students will:
  • Sing, alone and with others, a varied repertoire of music.
sing a variety of music with more than one voice part.
sing a variety of choral literature, e.g. regional, national, global.
expand use of metric accents, e.g., accent marks, tenuto.
sing major and minor melodies.
sing songs in a variety of global languages.
refine attacks and releases.
sing with expression that is consistent with the interpretation of the text.
sing intervals with good intonation, balance and blend.
demonstrate dark and bright vowel sounds.
refine, apply and build vocal technique through warm-ups and a variety of vocal literature.
sing a cappella music.
refine characteristics of ensemble singing, e.g., balance, blend and styles.
sing music containing contrasting dynamic levels.
sing literature with varied rhythmic patterns.
match pitch with good intonation.
sing repertoire to include a variety of tempi and meter changes.
develops accountability and personal productivity through practice habits.
Standard: Exploring

Students will:
  • Read and notate music
  • Listen to, analyze, and describe music
  • Evaluate music and music performances.
expand singing and exploration of various meters and tempo markings.
explain and explore major and minor tonalities.
identify and sing intervals from notation, e.g., major, minor, perfect.
read and sing melodies containing syncopation.
identify and vocally apply musical terms, expression marks and symbols.
identify the melodic and harmonic parts in a vocal piece.
sing from a choral score observing standard notation.
sight sing simple melodies.
identify musical phrases and forms.
discuss differences in singing various styles of music.
identify criteria for an outstanding performance.
evaluate live and recorded performances of themselves and others.
identify conducting patterns and gestures.
review and refine previously learned rhythms.
identify sixteenth notes and dotted rhythms.
Standard: Creating

Students will:
  • improvise melodies, variations, and accompaniments
  • compose and arrange music within specified guidelines
improvise rhythmic and melodic variations on a given melodic phrase.
create lyrics for a multi-section song, e.g., AB, ABA.
compose a vocal warm-up.
Standard: Relating

Students will:
  • understand relationships between music, the arts and disciplines outside the arts
  • understand music in relation to history and culture.
use information and communication technology to examine musical careers.
discuss the historical and global origins of a choral work.
discuss the anatomy of the human voice and how it affects vocal tone production.
discuss and demonstrate social responsibility through appropriate audience behavior.
discuss the literary merits of choral texts.
Standard: Performing

Students will
  • Sing, alone and with others, a varied repertoire of music.

demonstrate, apply and perform proper vocal technique (e.g., tone production, breathing, posture, vowel modification, attacks, releases, natural vibrato and straight tone) through a variety of choral literature.
sing a variety of choral literature with three or more vocal parts, e.g., SSA, SSAA, SAB, SATB, TTB.
perform a wide variety of choral literature with stylistic appropriateness and proper ensemble technique, e.g., intonation, balance, and blend.
expand repertoire of global language pieces.
sing polyphonic and a cappella compositions with appropriate stylistic tone quality.
perform characteristics of ensemble singing, e.g., balance, blend and styles.
perform music with expressive dynamic levels.
sing literature with complex rhythmic patterns.
demonstrates accountability and personal productivity through practice habits.
Standard: Exploring

Students will:
  • read and notate music
  • listen to, analyze, and describe music
  • evaluate music and music performances
aurally discern various meters and voice combinations.
sight sing his/her own part within multi-part score.
identify melodies, harmonic passages, and intervallic relationships with in a full vocal score.
discuss elements of music in a given choral example.
compare and contrast the various ways voices are combined in given choral works.
notate major/minor scales as they apply to choral selections studied.
evaluate and critique the choral performances of themselves and others.
discuss how the musical elements in a choral work elicit an emotional response.
perform compositions that are notated with non-traditional symbols.
compile a portfolio of performed choral music, musical performances, and a student-generated glossary.
examine and discuss a given choral composition using the appropriate musical terminology.
Standard: Creating

Students will:
  • improvise melodies, variations, and accompaniments
  • compose and arrange music within specified guidelines
embellish a known melody.
improvise a melody.
create harmonic parts or vocal accompaniments in a variety of musical styles.
compose a multi-part warm-up.
create rhythmic or melodic variations to a known melody.
Standard: Relating

Students will:
  • understand relationships between music, the arts and disciplines outside the arts
  • understand music in relation to history and culture.
use information and communication technology to research musical careers.
discuss the historical and cultural significance of a choral work.
discuss and demonstrate social responsibility through appropriate audience behavior in a given setting.
compare choral music with other arts from the same historical style period and global culture.
develop a concert program using designated choral literature.
analyze and explain how the elements of music can be used to evoke feelings and reflect the choral text.
Standard: Performing

Students will:
  • perform on instruments, instruments, alone and with others, a varied repertoire of music.
maintain a steady beat.
demonstrate correct hand and body positions to play piano.
perform repertoire at the beginner level.
perform block and broken chord patterns.
perform major scales, hands together, for one octave using correct finger patterns.
perform whole, half, quarter and eighth notes and their corresponding rests as well as dotted half notes.
perform contrasting dynamics, e.g., piano (p) and forte (f).
demonstrate a I, IV, and V chordal accompaniment.
perform simple piano duets.
perform staccato and legato.
perform crescendo and diminuendo.
Standard: Exploring

Students will:
  • read and notate music
  • listen to, analyze, and describe music
identify notes within the grand staff.
read and notate rhythms using whole, half, quarter and eighth notes and their corresponding rests as well as dotted half notes.
visually identify stepwise and skipwise patterns.
discuss functions of bar lines, measures, ties, accidentals, repeat sign, D.C. al Fine, D.S. al Fine and multiple endings.
read notation in 2/4, 3/4, and 4/4 meters.
sight read simple melodies.
identify various key signatures.
evaluate aspects of their own performance (e.g., correct pitch, rhythm, dynamics).
identify musical phrases and phrasing techniques.
identify and name the parts of the piano and their function.
listen to and evaluate exemplary piano performances.
Standard: Creating

Students will:
  • improvise melodies, variations and accompaniments
  • compose and arrange music within specified guidelines
harmonize a simple melody using I, IV, and V(7) chords.
improvise a short melody within specified guidelines.
compose a block chord accompaniment using I, IV, and V(7) chords.
Standard: Relating

Students will:
  • understand relationships between music, the other arts, and disciplines outside the arts
  • understand music in relation to history and culture
discuss the science of acoustics in relation to the piano (e.g., different lengths of strings and different thickness of strings produce different pitches).
research the history of the piano and related instruments.
discuss concert etiquette for the audience member and the performer.
discuss whether or not the piano is a member of either the percussion, string or the chordophone family.
Standard: Performing

Students will:
  • perform on instruments, instruments, alone and with others, a varied repertoire of music.
perform all previous rhythms and expands to sixteenth notes, dotted quarter and related rests maintaining a steady tempo.
continue to expand performing block and broken chord patterns to additional keys.
continue to perform I, IV, V(7) chordal accompaniments and expand to additional keys.
perform music with further contrasting dynamics, e.g., mezzo piano (mp) and fortissimo (ff).
perform all previous major scales, and expand to additional keys, with correct fingerings, both hands together, one octave, maintaining a steady tempo.
perform using the damper pedal in legato passages.
perform pieces in a variety of key signatures.
refine performance of piano duets.
Standard: Exploring

Students will:
  • read and notate music
  • listen to, analyze, and describe music
interpret fermatas and accents.
expand reading and notating pitches using the grand staff.
read and notate all previous rhythms and expand to include sixteenth notes, dotted quarter notes and related rests.
interpret tempo markings, e.g., quarter note = 60, or ‘adagio'.
read and demonstrate basic syncopated rhythmic patterns.
sight-read, both hands together at appropriate level of difficulty.
Standard: Creating

Students will:
  • improvise melodies, variations and accompaniments
  • compose and arrange music within specified guidelines
improvise a simple melody over given I, IV, and V(7) chords.
continue to accompany melodies using I,IV, and V(7) chords in different keys.
compose a short melody using proper phrase structure (antecedent/consequent) and phrase techniques.
Standard: Relating

Students will:
  • understand relationships between music, the other arts, and disciplines outside the arts
  • understand music in relation to history and culture
explore community opportunities for pianists
identify various roles that keyboard musicians perform
research electronic keyboards/ synthesizers and the role they play in popular music
compare the characteristics of a piece of piano music and another art form including the basic content of each, e.g., unity, variety, repetition and contrast.
Standard: Performing

Students will:
  • perform on instruments, instruments, alone and with others, a varied repertoire of music.
continue to refine major scales and arpeggios by increasing tempo and extending to two octaves.
perform pieces in which there are a wide variety of dynamic ranges.
perform pieces in both major and minor keys.
perform a graded solo.
perform minor scales and chords.
Standard: Exploring

Students will:
  • read and notate music
  • listen to, analyze, and describe music
sight-read at appropriate level.
analyze and discuss musical form within a studied work, e.g., AB form, rondo, piano sonata.
notate key signatures in order of sharps and flats.
listen to piano works representing different genres/periods and discuss form and style.
play cadences using I ,IV, V(7) chord pattern in all studied major keys.
evaluate their own musicianship to include phrasing, dynamics, rhythm, articulation, expression, and technique.
transpose by notating a simple piece to closely related keys.
continue to refine reading ornamental markings, e.g., grace notes, trill, turn, etc.
Standard: Creating

Students will:
  • improvise melodies, variations and accompaniments
  • compose and arrange music within specified guidelines
collaborate to compose a piece incorporating correct phrases, I, IV, V cadences, and within a given form.
improvise short melodies including steps and skips over specified chord progression.
play cadences using major/minor I, IV, V,I chord patterns and improvise over such cadences.
compose a short melody and experiment with variations on such melody.
compose an individual work within specified guidelines.
Standard: Relating

Students will:
  • understand relationships between music, the other arts, and disciplines outside the arts
  • understand music in relation to history and culture
relate musical styles/genres to periods and events in history.
discuss piano works that have been inspired by works of visual art.
listen to and discuss West Virginia pianists/composers, e.g., George Crumb, David Williams, Bob Thompson, etc.
compare piano techniques to those of other keyboard instruments, e.g., organ, electronic keyboards, celesta, etc.
research a piece of piano music, it's composer and investigate the motive and/or inspiration behind composing the piece.
Standard: Performing

Students will:
  • sing, alone and with others, a varied repertoire of music; and
  • perform on instruments, alone and with others, a varied repertoire of music.
match pitch with good intonation.
show appropriate tuning techniques.
sing folksongs, including ballads and gospel songs.
perform folk pieces on traditional instruments, e.g., guitar, banjo, mandolin, fiddle, dulcimer.
perform chords to play pieces in the keys of G, D, em.
perform twelve bar blues.
perform as member of an ensemble while demonstrating appropriate balance, blend, as well as tonal and rhythmic accuracy.
Standard: Exploring

Students will:
  • read and notate music;
  • listen to, analyze, and describe music; and
  • evaluate music and music performances
interpret tied notes, and simple syncopated rhythms.
interpret repeat signs, multiple endings, the measure repeat sign, D.S., D.C. al Fine, and fermata.
perform melodies and rhythms in meters of two, three, four.
read and interpret chord charts and tablature.
demonstrate a steady beat within pieces using standard notation including whole, dotted half, half, quarter, eighth, and sixteenth note and rest values plus dotted rhythms.
interpret the following dynamic markings: p, mf, f.
notate and play one-octave scales and modes .
play and sing melodies from a lead sheet.
use the technical vocabulary of music in discussion and analysis of pieces played and heard.
describe binary and ternary forms.
identify block and arpeggiated accompaniment styles.
listen to a piece of music, analyze the dominant elements of the piece that make it unique, interesting, and expressive, e.g., dynamics, tempo, variations, range, tonality, and modulations.
apply musical criteria to evaluations of their own performances and performances by others, e.g., good ensemble playing, tone quality, and technical accuracy.
notate a familiar melody.
demonstrate idiomatic playing techniques, e.g., hammer on and pull, grace notes, shuffle bowing, slides.
compare and contrast performances of exemplary models.
compare and contrast two different musical selections.
Standard: Creating

Students will:
  • improvise melodies, variations, and accompaniments; and
  • compose and arrange music within specified guidelines
improvise a chordal accompaniment utilizing down and up strokes appropriate to melodic rhythms and style.
improvise rhythmic and melodic variations.
create a break over a chord progression.
create and harmonize an original melody.
improvise a melody over a standard twelve bar blues.
Standard: Relating

Students will
  • understand relationships between music, the other arts, and disciplines outside the arts
  • understand music in relation to history and culture
compare phrases to sentences in language arts (antecedent and consequent phrases).
research and/or collect examples of folk music, folk art and lore.
describe how sound is produced on a string instrument, and relate this to the science of acoustics
research the global origin and use of an Appalachian folk instrument.
identify successful folk musicians and list their significant roles in the development of diverse styles and forms of folk music.
research the global origin of an Appalachian folk song or tune.
Standard: 1 Performing

Students will:
  • sing, alone and with others, a varied repertoire of music
  • perform on instruments, alone and with others, a varied repertoire of music
perform on instruments (e.g., recorder, piano, guitar, percussion).
sing or perform on instruments, music representing diverse genres and cultures.
perform a part in an ensemble.
use music technology to explore musical sounds in an expressive way.
Standard: 2 Exploring

Students will:
  • read and notate music
  • listen to, analyze, and describe music
  • evaluate music and music performances
follow an instrumental or vocal score.
identify categories of sounds, individual instruments and varied ensembles (i.e., vocal, instrumental, electronic).
explore musical sounds through technology.
review and refine previously learned notation and basic terms of musical expression.
identify and describe musical elements (e.g., rhythm, melody, harmony, form, timbre, texture).
listen to and describe the way musical elements change within a selection.
compare and contrast the way musical elements are used in various pieces.
explain personal preferences for specific musical works and styles using appropriate music terms.
evaluate a given musical work and determine how musical qualities or elements were used to evoke feelings.
develop an awareness of musical style and works associated with each style.
develop specific criteria to encourage active listening skills.
Standard: 3 Creating

Students will:
  • improvise melodies, variations, and accompaniments
  • compose and arrange music within specified guidelines
improvise melodies over a given chord structure.
create an accompaniment to a familiar song.
identify improvisation in various styles of music.
compose and perform music using notation.
arrange music for voices or instruments.
Standard: 4 Relating

Students will:
  • understand relationships between music, the other arts, and disciplines outside the arts
  • understand music in relation to history and culture
compare characteristics of music and another art form within a particular historical period or style.
compare the characteristics of music and another art form including the basic content of each (e.g., unity and variety, repetition and contrast).
discuss and analyze American musical heritage and culture.
discuss and analyze multi-cultural influences on music.
explore various opportunities to experience music in their community.
discuss the role of technology in the development of music.
describe distinguishing characteristics of representative music genres and styles from a variety of cultures.
explain appropriate audience behavior for the context and style of music performed within a particular setting.
research careers in music.
discuss and analyze the various uses of music.
Standard: 1 Performing

Students will:
  • sing, alone and with others, a varied repertoire of music
  • perform on instruments, alone and with others, a varied repertoire of music.
perform major and minor scales on an instrument.
perform chord progressions on a keyboard (e.g., I IV V I, etc.)
perform an original composition.
sing intervals using a system (e.g., solfeggio, numbers, letter names).
perform rhythm patterns in various meters.
perform a chordal accompaniment to a musical selection.
match pitch within their vocal range
Standard: 2 Exploring

Students will:
  • read and notate music
  • listen to, analyze, and describe music
  • evaluate music and music performances
review and refine musical terms and symbols.
read notation in treble and bass clefs.
read rhythms in various meter signatures including irregular and/or changing meters.
identify enharmonic tones.
identify intervals by sight and sound.
sight sing using a system (e.g., solfeggio, numbers, letter names).
notate major and minor scales with key signatures in both treble and bass clefs.
aurally identify major and minor tonalities (chords, scales, musical selections).
notate I, IV, and V chords in major and minor keys.
harmonize a melody line.
analyze given compositions for chords, keys, musical form and other compositional devices .
Standard: 3 Creating

Students will
  • improvise melodies, variations, and accompaniments
  • compose and arrange music within specified guidelines
improvise a melody above a given chordal accompaniment.
improvise a rhythmic pattern to a steady pulse.
employ technology (e.g., a music writing program) to notate an original composition.
compose a piece of music with a specified form, choosing traditional or nontraditional notation.
arrange a given composition for another medium
Standard: 4 Relating

Students will:
  • understand relationships between music, the other arts, and disciplines outside the arts
  • understand music in relation to history and culture
listen to exemplary compositions and compare and contrast compositional devices used.
research available careers in music.
explain the acoustical properties of musical sounds.
explore opportunities within their community for composers/arrangers.
